title: U.S. Futures Edge Up, Yen Dips, Treasuries Steady: Markets Wrap
text:
(Bloomberg) -- U.S. stock futures edged up and Asian shares declined as investors weighed prospects for reduced U.S.-China trade tensions against deepening political gridlock in Washington.

Asian equity benchmarks fell Wednesday after the biggest decline for the S&P 500 Index in a month on Tuesday, in the wake of Speaker Nancy Pelosi saying that the House is opening a formal impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump. U.S. futures were steady, suggesting limited market fallout for now from the move. The contracts added to gains after Bloomberg reported that China is preparing to buy more American pork. The yen fell, and Treasuries steadied after climbing Tuesday. European futures dipped.

While the new impeachment push threatens to stymie any legislative progress in Washington, the Republican party’s majority in the Senate could limit the chances of any attempt by Democrats to oust Trump. Pelosi’s announcement came after revelations that he pushed Ukraine’s government to investigate Joe Biden, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020.

Elsewhere, oil fell amid signs Saudi Arabia is making progress in restoring lost output following a drone attack on its facilities. New Zealand’s dollar was steady after the central bank said there was room to cut interest rates again if needed. The pound dropped as U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a crisis after Britain’s Supreme Court ruled that he’d broken the law by suspending Parliament.

In Japan, five-year government bond yields fell to match a record low, amid the broader rally in sovereign bonds. The yield dropped to a record low.

These are some key events coming up this week:

Chicago Fed President Charles Evans will discuss the economic outlook and monetary policy in Illinois on Wednesday.Thailand decides on monetary policy on Wednesday, followed by the Philippines on Thursday.Core PCE -- the Fed’s preferred inflation measure -- is forecast for 1.8%. That’s due Friday.

Here are the main moves in markets:

Stocks

Futures on the S&P 500 Index added 0.1%. The underlying gauge fell 0.8% on Tuesday.Japan’s Topix index fell 0.2% at the 3 p.m. close in Tokyo.South Korea’s Kospi index declined 1.3%.Hong Kong’s Hang Seng retreated 1.3%.The Shanghai Composite slid 0.8%.Euro Stoxx 50 futures declined 0.3%.

Currencies

The yen dipped 0.3% to 107.35 per dollar.The offshore yuan fell 0.2% to 7.1213 per dollar.The euro bought $1.0997, down 0.2%.The pound dropped 0.2% to $1.2466.The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rose 0.2%.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries was at 1.65%.Australia’s 10-year yield dipped one basis point to 0.95%.

Commodities

West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.7% to $56.87 a barrel.Gold was at $1,527.84 an ounce, down 0.3%.
